1. 《悖论：思维的魔方》，陈波 著，北京大学出版社，2013年。
2. 《悖论简史：哲学和心灵的迷宫》，[英]罗伊?索伦森 著，贾红雨译，北京大学出版社，2007年。
3. 《逻辑悖论研究引论》，张建军 著，南京大学出版社，2002年。

对悖论的思考，实际上是一种理智操练，其不仅可以锻炼我们的思考能力，更有助于培养一种理性思维态度。从对悖论的研究中，我们可以培养一种健康的怀疑主义态度，一种适当留有余地的态度，一种适度宽容的态度，以及进行批判性思考的能力，它们正好是教条主义和独断论的反面，也正好是大学教育最应该传授给学生的。因此，“悖论研究”应该成为大学教育的一门通识课程。而且，也已经有不少国内外大学开设了类似的通识教育课程。《悖论研究》课程的目标旨在以语形悖论、语义悖论和认知悖论以及合理决策的悖论等各种逻辑悖论为题材，让学生在对悖论的思考中，进行理智思维的训练，培养学生的理智能力和合理健康的思维态度。

课程的目的既不在于对悖论做全面的研究和探索，也不在于让学生记住都有哪些悖论然后对其置之不理。所以，实际的教学内容会从各类悖论中选取学生感兴趣的一些主题，进行深入的分析和讨论。
第一讲 绪论 （3课时）
讲授悖论的定义和类型，合理解决悖论的标准，悖论研究的意义，以及相关的逻辑学基础知识。

第二讲 二难困境 （3课时）
分析和探讨几个典型的二难困境，比如苏格拉底悖论、半费之讼和上帝的全知悖论。

第三讲 模糊性：连锁悖论 （3课时)
讨论与模糊性有关的连锁悖论，评述几种已有的解决模糊性悖论的方案：多值逻辑和真值度理论、超赋值主义、认知主义等。
       
第四讲   集合论悖论 （3课时）
讨论罗素悖论等集合论悖论。    

第五讲   语义悖论与真理论 （6课时）*
重点内容：讨论以说谎者悖论为代表的语义悖论，以及对语义悖论的新近研究：克里普克的解悖方案、菲尔德的解悖方案、说谎者悖论的“复仇”等。

第六讲  休谟问题和归纳悖论 （3课时）
讨论归纳问题和归纳悖论，如：休谟的归纳问题和古德曼的新归纳之谜等。

第七讲 认知悖论 （9课时）*  
重点内容：结合教师的研究讨论信念之谜、独断论悖论、盖提尔问题以及怀疑论悖论等。

第八讲   决策和合理行动的悖论 （3课时）
讨论博弈和决策相关的悖论。

第九讲   道德悖论 （3课时）
讨论与道德和义务相关的悖论。

The goal of this course is to investigate the justifications for government intervention in housing markets and to evaluate the different methods used by governments to shape them. Special attention will be paid to the efficacy of the various tools employed by planners and policymakers in rental and homeownership markets, the recent foreclosure crisis, and the impact of housing policy interventions on neighborhoods and communities. Much of the course will focus on the United States but international experiences will also be presented.

Modern society revolves around its cities, which are both stable and changing depending on where and how often you look.  California is more dynamic than Wisconsin, say, but less so than the Peoples Republic of China.  Yet how cities work is mainly understood through their various parts – streets, houses, etc. – and their functions – jobs, transportation, and so on.  These conflicts, and the issues they concern, are pivotal.  Some questions addressed are strictly positive; e.g., what is growth, what does infrastructure cost, how does urban development affect the quality of life?  Others are normative; e.g., should development be fast or slow?  There is much to learn about, first, how to think about how communities function and, second, what to do about it.
Public policies toward cities are mainly aimed at these pieces rather than at the whole, but an understanding of the whole (and its parts) makes for successful policies. 
This is a survey course of many such elements, aimed at helping you get your head around some big issues of the day, such as poverty and growth, by improving your familiarity with their details.  Among other issues, we will look at 4 major, related themes:
? Economic development and Community Development (including poverty)
? Housing markets 
? Public finances

Much modern evidence indicates that contemporary urban design and urban form are problematic for a host of reasons.  Land consumption for urban development is particularly a concern when converted from potentially more valuable land uses, including land devoted to scenic, recreational, and habitat purposes.  More city traffic jeopardizes our health, our sanity, and our pocketbook, as well as the environment.  The poor are isolated in or relegated to high crime and low amenity communities that cannot finance basic services and from which they cannot afford to leave.  Neighborhoods fail to function as they seemed to before, in part because the modern subdivision places social, physical and economic obstacles in their path.  Perhaps most plainly, many cities and indeed many new urban areas especially are both unattractive and uninspiring. 
The solutions tend toward bold policy interventions.  Cities should dramatically increase their densities, cars should be discouraged, open space should be removed from development, zoning codes should be burned, and so on.  Among other issues, we will focus on 2 major, related themes:
? Urban form (and alternatives)
? Traffic problems (and urban design solutions)
Land Use Planning: Processes, Institutions, Critiques, and Innovations
Land Use Planning: Processes, Institutions, Critiques, and Innovations

This course is designed to provide an understanding of the techniques, processes, strategies and dilemmas of land use planning, and uses land use institutions as a lens to understand urban development.The course will start with a review of the history of public land use control mechanisms, particularly zoning. It will aim to develop an understanding of the role of various institutions involved in the planning process. Next, we will discuss the main shortcomings of conventional land use planning. These include critiques of land use planning as an inefficient, capricious, inequitable, racist, sexist, deadening, immoral and illegal practice. The majority of the course will focus on governance innovations in land use planning policies and processes to address the preceding critiques.
An Introduction to The US Education and Human Resource Development Systems
An Introduction to The US Education and Human Resource Development Systems

This course will provide an overview of the workforce education and development systems in the United States at different stages and in different contexts (formal schooling and workplace education). Through this course, you will learn about the US secondary and post-secondary educational systems, trace the evolution of American education and examine its principles, characteristics, structure, process, delivery, policies, and challenges.

This course gives a brief introduction of educational policy in US and illustrates it with case analysis. It analyzes the development of educational policy, the trend and challenges of educational policy and also makes comparison of education policy between US and other countries.
美国的政府体制和教育
Introduction to American System of Government and Education

Students will learn about the managerial relationship between the American federalist system and the American system of education. Students will demonstrate basic and intermediate knowledge of American government and education systems
Part 1: Summary/description of American government system. Part 2: Description of American structure of K-12 school governance. Part 3: Relationships between federal, state, and local governments.
课程教师指导学生针对某一重大社会问题进行研究设计、社会调查与报告撰写
Plato and Platonism Soul, Body and Kosmos
Plato and Platonism Soul, Body and Kosmos

The course is aimed at an examination of Plato’s conception of the soul and its relation with the body in the individual living beings, but also in the context of physics and cosmology. These issues will be treated through a close reading of the relevant passages of Plato’s dialogues.

The course is aimed at an examination of Plato’s conception of the soul and its relation with the body in the individual living beings, but also in the context of physics and cosmology. These issues will be treated through a close reading of the relevant passages of Plato’s dialogues.
Defining Politics:A Cross-Historical Perspective (China, Europe And The Americas)
Defining "Politics":A Cross-Historical Perspective (China, Europe And The Americas)

This course proposes to continue the reflections that I have started in my seminars in Heidelberg in the last two years. We all know that the late 19th and early 20th centuries saw the consolidation of the German Staatslehre, the beginnings of the Chinese zhengzhi xue, and the American “political science.” They all dealt, in different ways, with “politics.” But parallel to the institutionalization of this discourse on “poltics,” other discourses (“scientific” and “non-scientific”) existed which were not forcibly taken into account by these embryonic sciences. How was the discourse on “politics” separated from the discourse of “customs,” of “letters” or of “ritual”? How was this discursive and institutional differentiation produced, how was it embedded in discursive and social networks across the globe in the early 20th century world? And how did this differentiation of a “political discourse” contribute to describe or even to generate both “political” and “non-political” institutions? In a cross-historical perspective, we will attempt to study the social networks within and beyond China that allowed to establish “politics” as a distinct sphere of knowledge and of social action.

Much modern evidence indicates that contemporary urban design and urban form are problematic for a host of reasons.  Land consumption for urban development is particularly a concern when converted from potentially more valuable land uses, including land devoted to scenic, recreational, and habitat purposes.  More city traffic jeopardizes our health, our sanity, and our pocketbook, as well as the environment.  The poor are isolated in or relegated to high crime and low amenity communities that cannot finance basic services and from which they cannot afford to leave.  Neighborhoods fail to function as they seemed to before, in part because the modern subdivision places social, physical and economic obstacles in their path.  Perhaps most plainly, many cities and indeed many new urban areas especially are both unattractive and uninspiring. 
The solutions tend toward bold policy interventions.  Cities should dramatically increase their densities, cars should be discouraged, open space should be removed from development, zoning codes should be burned, and so on.  Among other issues, we will focus on 2 major, related themes:
? Urban form (and alternatives)
? Traffic problems (and urban design solutions)

Sports and mega events, such as the Olympics, World Cup and Asian Games, play an important role in terms of culture, economics and their impact on cities.  This course will discuss the evolving role of sports as an economic and cultural phenomenon, with emphasis on the way that mega events are used by their host cities as a way to gain global visibility. This interdisciplinary course will focus on sports and mega events through economics, geography, business and urban planning.

This interdisciplinary course will focus on sports and mega events through economics, geography, business and urban planning.
This I Believe: A Look at Reflexive Writing
This I Believe: A Look at Reflexive Writing

This course will examine what it means to incorporate reflective thinking practices into academic writing. Reflexive writing is used extensively in Western educational contexts, including many colleges and universities. It is the use of writing to explore a personal response to experiences, situations, events, or new information. Reflexive writing can also be a process whereby thinking and learning take place. This is often one of the most challenging types of writing international students in the United States encounter since it requires a specific type of thinking that might not have been available to students before arriving in the United States.  
We will spend time talking about, and participating in, the reflective writing process, specifically through the lens of National Public Radio’s This I Believe series (thisibelieve.org). The instructor has taught using this model internationally in both the United States and Europe. Students will improve upon this Western-style of writing and will leave with class with a completed This I Believe essay reflective of their own thoughts and beliefs.

This course introduces students to major issues involving security in the Asia-Pacific region, using theory and empirical approaches to security studies. Topics will include the development of security cooperation and organisations, peacebuilding, counter-terrorism and non-traditional security challenges, and the linkages between economics and security. Specific case studies from East and Southeast Asia will be used to explain the development of security studies in the Pacific Rim since the end of the cold war for students new to the subject.
学生就公共管理领域的研究内容进行论文的选题、写作和答辩。
精彩跨校之间的案列辩论和点评，一直是这门高人气大课的名片
